Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: An integrated theory of syntactic acquisition - Realistic input, quantitatively defined target states, and computational models of the learning strategy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how the human mind creates the intricate system of syntactic structure that underlies human language has long been a central question in cognitive science. A complete theory of the cognitive architecture scaffolding this complex process needs to specify at least three components: (i) the input children use to learn their language's syntax, (ii) the gradient adult syntactic behavior that serves as the target state for learning, and (iii) the learning mechanism that children use to map between the input and the target state. The field is closer than ever to constructing its first set of large-scale theories because both the computational and experimental methodologies necessary to specify these components are now available to researchers willing to combine their expertise.

This project leverages a research framework that integrates realistic data about children's input, experimental syntax techniques, and computational modeling approaches to explain how children successfully acquire knowledge of multiple syntactic phenomena. The goal is to integrate the successful learning strategies for several complex syntactic phenomena into a cohesive theory of syntactic acquisition, identifying what the necessary elements of each strategy are and how children would know to utilize these strategy elements in just the right way. This represents a major advance for theoretical linguistics, developmental linguistics, and the broader psycholinguistics community, as it connects theoretical and experimental work in linguistics with computational modeling to yield broader insights than ever before.

This project provides an empirical foundation for studies of syntactic acquisition and a template for future projects that involve a coordinated synthesis of theory, experimentation, and computation. In addition, it provides hands-on research experience in theoretical linguistics to multiple undergraduate students and a graduate student each year, giving them access to professors engaged in highly relevant research that promises to have a significant impact on the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary focus of this project has been to extend an existing empirically-grounded, quantitative research framework and apply that framework to new developmental data. This has allowed us to create a more complete theory of both the biological factors (nature) and the environmental factors (nurture) that give rise to human knowledge of complex language structure. To this end, we have pioneered an integrated framework of the language development process that harnesses multiple state-of-the-art techniques (corpus analysis, experimental meta-analysis, and cognitive computational modeling). We have used this framework to investigate current theories of both complex linguistic knowledge and how that knowledge develops in children.

Intellectual Merit

We have generated more empirical resources that make possible the kind of integrated quantitative approach we advocate:

(i) a large corpus of the input data that children encounter, annotated with the linguistic and non-linguistic information children may be able to extract from these data

(ii) a set of large-scale corpora of quantified acceptability judgments for a wide range of phenomena that are critical to adult grammars

(ii) a large meta-analysis of child behavioral studies synthesizing what we know about what they know by ages three, four, and five about how verbs are used in their language

We have used these empirical resources ourselves to investigate the cognitive underpinnings of children’s observable complex linguistic behavior, based on the input they encounter at different ages. Computational modeling analysis has suggested a specific developmental trajectory highlighting what knowledge children have at different ages and how that knowledge changes, in addition to how children leverage the data available. These findings underscore that part of what was previously believed to be innate knowledge of how verbs work may instead be learned from the input. Preliminary followup work has identified a precise learning strategy for that verb knowledge, given the input children encounter. This learning strategy notably relies on some innate knowledge, but far less than was previously thought. Additional followup work has begun to investigate input differences across socio-economic status (SES); preliminary findings suggest that for some complex linguistic knowledge, there is little difference in children’s input across SES. This notably contrasts with the differences across SES that have been found for more foundational aspects of linguistic knowledge.

Broader Impacts

We have promoted our integrated quantitative research framework in the research community, highlighting both its benefits and caveats. This has caused more developmental and theoretical researchers to consider this framework for their own investigations. We have additionally made the empirical resources about children’s language input and children’s behavioral output available to the research community, thereby providing the empirical grounding for many future investigations into development of complex language knowledge. Moreover, our discovery that certain aspects of complex linguistic development don’t depend as much on innate knowledge underscores the impact that a child’s linguistic input has. That is, while nature (and innate knowledge) still has a role to play, so does nurture — and more specifically the child’s environment. This suggests more attention should be focused on the nature of the input that allows successful linguistic development (scaffolded by the necessary innate knowledge), and what the range of sufficient input is. A related finding is that, unlike other more foundational aspects of linguistic knowledge, the input for certain complex linguistic knowledge development doesn’t seem to differ across SES. This implies that once low-SES children are able to leverage the complex linguistic input available to them, they can succeed in developing complex linguistic knowledge the same way high-SES children do.

More generally, this project underscores the linguistic genius of children learning their native language, and what aspects of language development are particularly astonishing, given the data children have to learn from. Moreover, this project can also bring to light quantitative and qualitative differences in the input children receive at different ages that impact their ability to successfully acquire subtle aspects of their native language. This can provide the scientific foundation for clinical interventions and public policy related to the linguistic input children receive. In particular, there are components of children’s linguistic development that depend on the right input being available in their environment and that input may be susceptible to both (i) variation (a potential problem that can be identified), and (ii) effective intervention (a potential solution to that problem). Importantly, we can identify which components of linguistic development are subject to variation and effective intervention so that resources can be focused where they will be most beneficial to children.
